div1.head: Letter from John H. Andrus to Albert E. Truby, January 22, 1942
div1.opener:
From J. H. Andrus - 805 Cooper Street - Camden, New Jersey.
Jan. 22, 1942.
Dear General:
div1.p:
Received your manuscript on the fifteenth, read most of the
night and expected to send it on within a day or two; unfor-
tunately there have been more visitors and other interrupt-
ions than usual so it will not go to Mrs. LaGarde until to-
morrow - Friday.

This is a grand bit of writing and - even in the cockeyed
days through which we are living - I do not think you should
have any trouble finding a publisher.

There is little that I can offer. Knowing your desire for
absolute accuracy, however, I offer the following:
Preceding p 40 “Key to buildings shown on map”.
“91 Wards, including office”. No wards. S. end of bldg.
was Post Surgeon's office. Remainder of S. half was gen'l.
office. In N. half of 91 pharmacy was next to office and
storeroom and quarters for one or two non coms in remainder.
“92 Pharmacy, etc.” Wrong. At S. end of S. half were
one or two small, private rooms. Remainder of S. half was
medical and receiving ward. At N. end of 92 was partition
of bars to form lock ward to hold 4 to 6 beds. Remainder
of N. half of 92 was venerial ward.
“93” This was surgical and convalescent ward.
Between 91 and 92 there was a building housing toilets and
bath which is not shown. Only entrance to this building
was from center passage - across walk from boiler house.
There was a hall or passage between the N. and S. halves of 92
so patients from 93 could enter toilet building without having
to go around 92 as would have been the case if map was correct.
104 - 110 - 122 I recall but one building in this general loca-
tion in 1901 and 1902 and that was occupied by female nurses.
As I recall, there were from 6 to 8 nurses which would make 110
seem too small for quarters, mess and bath. 104 or 122
seems more probable.
p 67 “H” on diagram should read, “small addition in which guinea
pigs were housed”.
General Truby
Page 2.
p 73 - 74 - 75 having to do with the yellow fever epidemic at Guan-
ajay Barracks.

My recollections of some phases of this episode are very dis-
tinct and amazingly vague on others. In my one-volume book,
“Big Moments In A Little Life”, I have recorded what I remember
under the title, “My First Meeting With Yellow Fever” A copy
is enclosed.

Please bear in mind that, while you are recording a historical
event for publication, I only explain a purely personal “big
moment” to a limited audience of relatives and friends who know
none of those involved except myself.

You will note that I have refrained from naming any of the doc-
tors. That is due to uncertainties. When Schwieger and
I reached Guanajay Captain Quinton was the Post Surgeon.
He had an assistant but I am unable to recall his name.

From a day or two after I reached the Post until I was on duty
at the yellow fever hospital I was on night duty. As there
was seldom occasion for the doctors to visit the wards at
night, I had absolutely no contact with them.

That you replaced Captain Quinton as Post Surgeon registered
as I had known you at Columbia Barracks.

It is strongly in my mind that you were absent from the Post
for a few days prior to the death of the case which started
our epidemic. And it seems to me that you returned just
a few hours before his death. The fact that these are
impressions - rather than certainties - is why they were omit-
ted from my manuscript.

At the (tent) yellow fever hospital, the
first doctor I recall is Dr. Robert P.
Cooke. He was on duty but a few days
when replaced by Dr. John F. Dunshie.
Of these facts I am certain but I do not
know whether either of them had been on
duty at Guanajay before the epidemic.
My guess is that Dr. Cooke may have re-
placed your (and Capt. Quinton's) former
assistant and that Dr. Dunshie, (an im-
mune and probably a yellow fever special-
ist), was sent to handle the yellow fever
situation.

If any of this is helpful I shall be very glad. You and I
both know that it is not too easy to grope back through the
mists of more than 40 eventful years and always come up with
all the details of an involved situation.
